result.title: Collection of good practices from SOLUTIONSplus capacity building activities
result.description: As part of this task, experiences and good practices arising from the cooperation with cities and regions across the world will be compiled (D2.6). These good practices will be used in Task 2.3 to enrich training sessions with practical examples of deployment of e-mobility and they will contain a description of challenges, solutions, business models and approaches to deployment. Regional experiences from Task 2.4 will be adapted to be part of the training material and will be integrated also into the SOLUTIONSplus toolbox.In addition to the on-site trainings and workshops, the SOLUTIONSplus will also develop a self-paced eLearning activity (following the successful example of CAPITAL eLearning project) that will enable stakeholders globally to participate in knowledge sharing activities. In addition, webinars will be held by experts in the field and the recorded webinars will be shared as learning material for the eLearning participants. The Mobility Academy and other partner platforms will be used for the SOLUTIONSplus eLearning. This activity will be reported upon in the eLearning report (D2.5). The participants of the knowledge sharing activities of the SOLUTIONSplus project will be invited to be a part of an online community where the participants have the opportunity to share their experiences with other participants and query experts on electric mobility. The community of practice will also maintain a database of experts, organisations and businesses categorised into their specific electric mobility offering.

result.title: Impact assessment results
result.description: The scope of evaluation will be twofold: i) Cross-cutting evaluation on selected key impact areas will be performed to gain insight on the overall potential of the e-mobility services in different urban environments around the world. ii) In addition, selected demonstration project specific KPIs will be evaluated to address issues specific to certain types of areas or circumstances. The assessment will be documented in a way that enables meaningful geographic comparisons and transferability to other settings. This supports subsequent scaling up of projects and activities in each region. Results of this task will feed into the toolbox (Task 1.1) and thus allow decision makers to gain insight on the impacts of the measures on the investigated areas.

result.title: Catalogue of e-mobility solutions
result.description: This task will collect and categorise key concepts and business options related to available e-mobility solutions, the result will be a searchable database and an illustrated catalogue accessible online (D3.1). Both the database and the catalogue will inform on the available e-mobility concepts for implementation in the partner cities (and other cities). The catalogue will seek inputs and be distributed to the industry partners (also beyond the consortium). The concepts and business options will include products/services of European industry players that are feasible for implementation in the partner cities/countries. The catalogue will also be a part of the SOLUTIONSplus showcase of e-mobility solutions. The catalogue will be accessible online in an interactive and user-friendly design, and the partners will be able to easily update the information at regular intervals. References to the experience from other cities and places, which have implemented the options, will be made on online catalogue. The catalogue will be open for all e-mobility providers (also beyond the consortium) and will feature both passenger and freight solutions, charging technologies, vehicle type and services that are available for e-mobility implementation. The following partners will contribute to some of the sections of the catalogue:•Vehicles: FIER (lead) in consultation with CRF, Volvo, Valeo, Piaggio•Operations: VTT (lead) in consultation with ABB, T-Systems, IDIADA, UITP•Integration: V2C2 (lead) in consultation with Pluservice, Dynniq

result.title: User needs assessments
result.description: Building on the evaluation framework, this task analyses user needs. Taking into account the needs of demonstration actions and the objectives for evaluation, the different user groups of e-mobility passenger and freight technologies and services will be identified. These can include different groups of travellers including persons with reduced mobility and elderly, commuters etc. System Domain Analysis Methodology will be used to “draw” the profile of the users. This methodology will take into account all the aspects of the system (environment, user behaviour, mobility components, sociology components, user journeys, etc.) to identify the root causes. The systems investigation will be fed by an in-field research through surveys or interviews. UITP will involve the local demo partners (WP4) to define the user needs and perform in-field research (e.g. with interviews or surveys). Finally, the user-level feedback will be compiled to determine user groups and use cases and commonalities between them (use case groups). Use cases help in finding commonalities – based on vehicles, transport services, user profiles, among others - between different demonstration projects, and in providing structure and guidance to demonstration projects and give a frame for evaluation and reporting.

result.title: Capacity building tools and updates
result.description: The needs assessment will be led by UN-Habitat and informed through the experience of partners like Polis, UITP, CODATU and ERTICO. These partners amassed valuable experience through projects such as, CIVITAS2020, the EU SUMP take-up project’s cluster, the CAPITAL H2020 project and the ITS Academy, and other EU projects. The needs assessment will cover aspects such as local and national policy and regulatory frameworks, integrated energy and environment planning and management, technologies, business and financial models, access and integration, vision building and strategy development (see list of trainers and thematic leads in task 2.5). The outcomes of the needs assessment and gap analysis will form the basis of the SOLUTIONSplus capacity building plan and needs assessment (D2.1), which will be revised and updated mid-way the project. This plan will outline: •the themes and curriculum of e-mobility training modules (online and face-to-face) (task 2.2); •outline the contributions of the SOLUTIONSplus toolbox (WP1) to the capacity building; •the sequence, location and timing of training, capacity and skills building activities: the peer-to-peer programme for SOLUTIONSplus cities (task 2.3) the training schedule, to be undertaken by internal (and affiliated) expert organizations of the SOLUTIONSplus consortium (task 2.5 – see the table below); this schedule will take into account the local measure implementation cycle (planning, implementation, evaluation, upscaling and deployment) as well as regional and global key events that can be synergized with SOLUTIONSplus capacity building activities;•training opportunities from partner projects and initiatives;•the structure of the capacity building ecosystem (task 2.5).

result.title: Five (5) proposals for National Urban Mobility Programmes
result.description: This task will take concrete steps towards financing large scale, transformative implementation projects based on the learning from the demonstration activities.Funding: This task will aim to align e-mobility solutions to national frameworks and priorities and will work with national governments on Urban Mobility Programmes that help rolling-out e-mobility solutions more widely across the country. A particular focus for this task will be on the development of national funding programmes for public and shared e-mobility solutions in cities. In close cooperation with the MobiliseYourCity, Euroclima+, IntraACP and the GEF-7 sister project, dialogues with the national governments in the partner countries will be facilitated with the objective of launching dedicated programmes for e-mobility for local authorities and local public transport operators. The demonstration activities in the SOLUTIONSplus partner cities will act as reference points for the national roll-out. Financing: For large-scale projects such as e-BRT lines, financing from domestic or multilateral banks and financing mechanisms will be required. The SOLUTIONSplus and GEF-7 projects will work directly with partner development banks, e.g. those involved in the GEF 7 sister project (ADB, AfDB, IDB, WB) and those involved in the MobiliseYourCity partnership (AFD, KfW, EBRD) and CAF. As part of the wider programme, financial institutions will be involved early in the scoping and panning of the transformational projects based on the demo actions, which will allow a close alignment to funding priorities and will enable the consortium to address specific requests from the bank during the demo and analysis phases. Procurement: The 30 partner cities and national governments involved in the joint SOLUTIONSplus and GEF-7 programme will bring a critical mass when it comes to the procurement of electric vehicles. The project partners will facilitate procurement round tables with providers of e-mobility solutions with a view to negotiate more favourable conditions for local and national authorities. These procurement round tables will be facilitated by UN Environment and will be supported by the regional coordinators (CAA, ITDP, CMM).
